The 'palate' () is the roof of the mouth in humans and other mammals. It
separates the oral cavity from the nasal cavity. Wingerd, 166 A
similar structure is found in crocodilians, but, in most other tetrapods, the
oral and nasal cavities are not truly separate. The palate is divided into two
parts, the anterior bony '[[hard palate]]', and the posterior fleshy '[[soft
palate]]' or 'velum'. Wingerd, 478 Clayman, 1995 Gray's
Anatomy, 1172 The maxillary nerve branch of the trigeminal nerve (V)
supplies sensory innervation to the palate.

The hard palate forms before birth. If the fusion is incomplete, it is called a
cleft palate. As the roof of the mouth was once considered the seat of the
sense of taste, palate can also refer to this sense itself, as in the phrase "a
discriminating palate". By further extension, the flavor of a food
(particularly beer or wine) may be called its palate, as when a wine is said to
have an oaky palate.
